Posts.Content: May 9, 2013 10:46PM Eloise wrote: Unfortunately, having previous benign microcalcifications doesn't mean you can't have cancer in the future.  I had one round of calcs that came back benign -- and a doc who pooh-poohed the idea that I'd even been told to get a biopsy.  Two years later, I had DCIS in the same area*.  So I'd think about finding a way to get a biopsy; if your current GP can't or won't order it, can you find a new specialist?  (*And a little more than two years after finishing treatment, everything's great and my mammos have been clear.)
Posts.Title: 2nd lot of microcalcifications yogimojy mustang12

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2011 02:05PM Eloise wrote: Hi ScariedCat, I've had two stereotactic core biopsies.  The procedure will probably take about an hour total.  I'm not going to lie to you, it's not comfortable -- mostly because you have to lie face down on the table with your head turned to one side, and you have to lie very still for most of it since you want to make sure they're getting to the right millimeter of tissue.  You might want to take a Tylenol beforehand if you have any problems with your back or neck, and try to relax -- I know that's easier said than done.  But in my experience, the biopsy is not especially painful; you'll feel a twinge when you get the anesthetic injection and you may or may not have a quick bit of pain when they take the tissue samples -- one of mine was a bit painful and one wasn't, just seems to have been a matter of where there were a few more nerve endings.  Not anywhere near as bad as dental work I've had.  The people doing the biopsy won't be able to see anything more than the radiologist who read the mammogram saw -- calcifications.  The pathologist who looks at the cells under the microscope will be the one to see whether there are cellular changes.  So don't worry about trying to figure out what the doctor and the techs are thinking...but do tell them that you're really scared and nervous, so they can do the best job they can of explaining things to you.  After the biopsy, you'll want to wear a sports bra if you have one, something that gives an extra bit of compression, to reduce any internal bleeding.  You'll probably have some bruising, it'll feel tender and you'll see discoloration for a few days.  This is normal -- the doctor or staff should give you some aftercare instructions about what to do if it seems like it's more than usual.  They'll also give you a cold-pack to put in your bra, usually a very small round one; if you have one at home, put in in the freezer now for when you get home, or you can just use a bag of frozen peas!  I went back to work right after one of my biopsies, the other one happened to be scheduled for after my shift so I didn't have to.  You should get the results in three to five days, though it can vary depending on whether your doctor uses an in-house pathologist or has to send the sample somewhere, and how busy they are. It's okay to be scared, this is all very new and unknown.  Don't worry more than you have to, and remember to breathe.  Hang in there and let us know how it goes.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Tomorrow ScariedCat ScariedCat

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 08:51PM Eloise wrote: Liz, I'm glad the biopsy wasn't too unpleasant for you.  Get some rest, both physical and mental if you can.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Tomorrow ScariedCat ScariedCat

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2011 08:37AM Eloise wrote: I had a lumpectomy with no node biopsy and had what is referred to as "conscious sedation" -- not as deep as a general, I didn't need to have a breathing tube.  But I don't remember a thing from when I was being wheeled into the OR until I woke up in recovery an hour or so later.  I'd already had some local anesthesia earlier in the day when they put in a wire to guide the surgeon, and after it went in I didn't feel a thing.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy Procedure - Question travelgal6979 Fearless_One

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2011 11:57AM Eloise wrote: Oh, profbee, I'm sorry to hear that it wasn't benign.  Welcome to the club.  Yes, you do have breast cancer (unless the pathologist is totally wrong).  If it is all DCIS, that is a comparatively good result -- DCIS is not invasive, so there is no chance of it spreading beyond the breast, so no need to even consider chemo.  However, even if there is an invasive component, that doesn't mean you will need chemo, it means it's something that you and your doctors will look at as part of the range of treatment options.  What's also comparatively good is that your doctor is thinking lumpectomy; that implies he's only seeing a relatively small single area of concern.  I'd suggest that you go over to the DCIS board and read up there, if you're up for it....if not, go for a walk or read something that has nothing to do with breast cancer.  I'd suggest Trollope, but you're the English professor! But, here's a couple of things to think about and perhaps talk about at your appointment tomorrow.  You should do some research and thinking about the sentinel node biopsy (SNB) and lymphedema. SNB is not indicated for DCIS, only invasive cancer (and not always then).  The "pro" of doing it right away with the lumpectomy is that you only have one surgery, one recovery period, and depending on your insurance it may be less expensive.  The "con" is that the SNB exposes you to the risk of lymphedema.  So an alternative plan would be do the lumpectomy, then do the SNB later if it's indicated by the results of the lumpectomy.  Two surgeries, but less risk.  My perception from reading other posts here is that many surgeons underestimate the risk or the impact of lymphedema -- it happens to patients after they've left the surgeon's care.  In my case, the surgeon presented it as an option in a very neutral way; when I said I didn't want the SNB at this time, he said "Yes, I agree with that", but I wouldn't have known to say that if I hadn't already been researching here and elsewhere. The other thing is that reading the pathology of DCIS is a very fine art. See this NYTimes article: www.nytimes.com/2010/07/20/hea...   It sounds like the pathologist on your case is already getting outside help, if not a formal second opinion; but you can also request a second opinion.  Usually this is done after the lumpectomy when you have the whole cancer to look at and not just the biopsy sample, but you could do it now if you think the results would change your surgical plan.  If you search here under "DCIS" and "second opinion" I think you'll find a number of people who've had different results with a second pathologist. This is still not an emergency and you don't need to rush into a decision, so take the time you need. All the best.
Posts.Title: NOW what do I know? profbee profbee

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2011 06:48PM Eloise wrote: I had my setup, CT, and tats today -- all went well, I was blessed with rather cute young men as CT techs! -- and met with the nurse who advises on skin care and such. She recommends Cetaphil cream 4x a day and not within 2 hours of treatment, plus Zeasorb powder for any rashes as needed.   She also sent me off to the fabric store to buy two yards of "ultra-cuddly" white fleece, which she recommends cutting into large strips and wearing next to the skin on the radiated side to prevent the bra, camisole, or other clothing from irritating.  Since the fabric store is one of my weaknesses, it amused me to be sent there under medical orders! I have a tentative start time of next Wednesday, but it may be pushed back a week because I've opted to have my tissue tested for HER2 status (usually not done for DCIS) so that I can participate in a clinical trial if I'm HER2+.  I'm not sure I'm going to go ahead with it if I get chosen for the Herceptin cohort, but I'd like to advance the science if I can.

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2011 06:14PM Eloise wrote: Pennythoughts, that's exactly what I was thinking about my tattoo.  It doesn't look like a mole or a freckle, it looks like someone jabbed a lead pencil between my breasts and the tip broke off.  It's also not quite symmetrical -- which I know isn't the point -- but it is a bit annoying, like a picture that won't hang quite straight. I'm going to start looking for tattoo artists who specialize in post-rads coverup art!  And mjbmiller, I had the "don't be helpful" lecture too -- one of my techs said "Just lie there like a sack of sugar and let us do the work".  I had the feeling that he had started out saying "sack of potatoes" to patients, and been told that wasn't a very flattering image.   I forgot to mention when I was talking to the nurse yesterday, I asked her about swimming -- I go to the high school pool a few blocks away, but it is chlorinated.  She said not a problem, but to cover the radiated area with a layer of Vaseline first.  But stay out of hot tubs and spas, and no hot showers.  That might be the most difficult part of the treatment for me -- I dearly love a hot shower at the end of the day.

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 06:41PM Eloise wrote: #2 of 25 today. I've been using Cetaphil moisturizing cream three or four times a day since last week, which was what my doctor's nurse had recommended.  About two hours after I came home from #1 yesterday, I started having hot and itchy sensations on that side, especially under my breast.  Went to take a look and it was definitely pinker than it was in the morning.  So I put on some aloe and also some calendula-aloe ointment that I got at a health food store...actually billed as baby cream for diaper rash, but whatever.  That helped.  Today when I got home from #2 I put the aloe on immediately, and didn't have the pinkness, and less of the itchiness.  I'm still using the Cetaphil too.  Later in the afternoon, I had an appointment with one of my other doctors unrelated to the cancer. My HMO prints out a reminder on every co-pay receipt of any upcoming appointments, tests you're supposed to have, immunizations due etc.  The receptionist pulled mine off the computer and said "Oh, something screwed up here....it says you have all these appointments at the same time every day for weeks, and it isn't even with a doctor, it's with a machine!"
Posts.Title: January 2011 Rads suzieq60 msjag

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 07:04PM Eloise wrote: tamos, what I understood from my doctor and the education program at my clinic is that cancer cells are especially sensitive to radiation because they are devoting so much of their energy to spreading and multiplying, which normal cells are not.  The radiation affects normal cells too, but they have the strength to recover, but the cancer cells don't and will die.  The level of radiation we're getting is what experience has shown is enough to kill the cancer cells without doing permanent damage to too many of the normal cells.  The question about whether mammograms expose us to too much radiation is related to the risk versus the benefit.  If 1 out of a million women gets cancer because of a mammogram, but 10,000 women have a cancer discovered and treated because of a mammogram, that's a risk most women will take. I just made those numbers up, so don't quote them, but the point is the number of cancers that will be detected because of a mammogram is much higher than the numbers caused.  But that's also why routine mammograms aren't recommended for 25-year-olds, even though there are a few 25-year-old women on this board with breast cancer -- the number of cancers that will be detected is much lower, so it doesn't seem worth the risk to give every 25-year-old the extra bit of radiation.  Does that make sense?  It's good that people are cautious about radiation now -- when my mom was a teenager she got X-rays for mild acne, and even when my older sisters were kids there was an X-ray machine at the shoe store they used to see how well the kids' feet fit the shoes.  Those were totally unnecessary exposures where the risk was much higher than the benefit.  Mammograms and dental X-rays are worth it for most of us.
Posts.Title: January 2011 Rads suzieq60 msjag

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 06:32PM Eloise wrote: Today I went for an informational tour of the radiation oncology facility I'm going to (Kaiser in South San Francisco) -- it's optional, but recommended for all new patients.  Very nice program, for all types of cancer although I think most of us were BC patients. First one of the dosimetricians showed us around the building, took us into the CT room, one of the treatment suites, and then brought us into a conference room for a PowerPoint presentation about the theory of radiation, showing samples of CT scans overlaid with how the dose was being targeted, etc.  When he got to showing us the scans he told us the prostate cancer we were looking at was his own -- which he had been treated for a few months ago.  Then one of the nurses came in and told us to stop by the nursing station any time if we had questions -- "we're always busy, but we're never too busy to talk to patients".  The nutritionist came by and said if any of us had questions about food, feel free to stop in, and the social worker gave us the rundown on what she could do to find us rides if we needed them, put through disability and medical leave paperwork, etc.  Really nice and took care of a lot of the minor procedural questions -- I'd had a little bit of health education from the nurses the day I came in for my consultation with the oncologist, but at that point I was convinced that I wasn't getting rads and was just here to confirm it was unnecessary....so I didn't pay as much attention as I should.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 11:37PM Eloise wrote: By the way, if any of you ever are bitten by a cat -- even your own cat who's definitely not rabid or anything -- call your doctor sooner rather than later.  I had stuff to do today, so I ignored my swelling hand until after dinner, when I had a moment to sit down and check my health plan's interactive advice program.  It said "Please seek immediate medical attention".  Then I called the advice nurse line, hoping they would say "just take some Advil and use an ice bag".  The nurse said "Well, it looks like the urgent care clinic just closed 15 minutes ago...so I'm sorry, but you need to go to the ER".  (It wasn't that bad -- only two hours' wait.  But if I'd done it earlier in the day, it might have been half an hour at the less hectic urgent care.)  Now I have two weeks' worth of antibiotics, maybe they'll even help my peeling skin!

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 09:20PM Eloise wrote: Welcome new friends, congratulations to those who are graduating from Curie U.  I did #3 of 25 today. The slight itchiness and redness I had the first day seems to have gone away, my doc said it was quite common to have some redness after treatment #1 -- it's not the same kind of skin reaction as will come later on, but a first response to inflammation under the skin, the cells saying "Hey! What's up with that?".  He also showed me exactly what areas were being radiated so I could be sure to put the cream on.  That was interesting because it wasn't all where I had expected -- my lumpectomy scar is on the lower outer side and I'd sort of thought of the scar as being the center of the radiation, but it's actually hitting all the way up to the clavicle, because of the angle they're taking to avoid the lung.

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2010 08:35PM - edited Dec 30, 2010 08:39PM by Eloise Hello all, is there room for one more?  Looks like I will be starting rads sometime in mid-January, I have my planning session next Wednesday 1/5.  I had a lumpectomy for DCIS on November 17, and when the path report came back my surgeon told me it looked so good he didn't think I'd need any further treatment...but he sent me for a consult with the oncology department as a matter of routine.  I saw the medical oncologist a week later but didn't get to see the radiation oncologist until the day before Christmas Eve, and was somewhat surprised when he recommended 25 sessions of rads. I've decided to go ahead with radiation but declined the offer of tamoxifen.  It may be overtreating for a very small cancer, but I think I'll have more peace of mind with it.  Very glad to have all the shared information and experience here!  I might also be participating in a clinical trial for herceptin for DCIS, if it turns out that my cancer was HER2+.

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 12:22PM Eloise wrote: msjag, I've got a sleep disorder related to my work shift, and I've tried melatonin at the suggestion of one of my docs and it's been helpful, but not as much as I'd like.  It's certainly worth a try; check with your doc about dosage, mine says the recommended dose on the label is actually too low to do much good for most people. Some people think the liquid is more effective, especially the kind that comes in an eyedropper to be taken under the tongue. It's also supposed to be important for sleep disturbance that when you go to bed, lie down and shut your eyes; don't sit up, read, watch TV, or listen to the radio in bed, and keep your room as dark as possible.  I don't practice any of this, mind you!  I don't have a TV in my bedroom, but I've been reading in bed every night since I learned to read, and can't get to sleep without the radio on. I never had sleep issues before I got assigned to the shift I have now, though. I had great results with Ambien for about two weeks and then I had a freaky amnesia attack one morning after taking it, which put me off it.  Sleep is really important to healing, so don't neglect it.  I'm already on leave from work even though I'm only on #7 of rads, mostly because I don't sleep well when I'm working my usual shift.

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2011 01:34PM Eloise wrote: Re bloodwork -- I haven't had any before or during rads, nor did I have any before my surgery; but I had had a routine CBC panel in June of this year, which may have been enough.  Also, it may be that bloodwork is not so important for DCIS and/or people not having chemo.  As far as doctor and staff communications, I have to say that my team has been fantastic.  I have Kaiser, which is a "closed" HMO with its own staff and facilities.  I think they've made a great effort to train their people to ask at least once during every appointment "Do you have any questions? Is there anything else I can do for you?".  They have a health library where I could check out books and videos, and online education before the biopsy and surgery. As I think I mentioned earlier in the thread, they had a Radiation 101 session before treatment started; I got a tour of the facilities, explanations of how the machine worked, what the different techs did, etc. and got introduced to everyone who would be on my team.  Kaiser has an online component that allows me to make or change my own appointments and email any of my doctors, and I've always had replies by the next day.  There've been a couple of small things -- my surgeon didn't offer me a copy of my pathology report, I had to ask for it; the medical oncology nurse-practitioner who gave me the pitch for tamoxifen didn't have statistics about how much risk it would reduce, and it took her a couple of weeks to get back to me -- but overall I've been really pleased.  And my out-of-pocket costs for all of my treatment are going to total about $200.

When I had my exit interview with the nurse yesterday, she told me to step up the lubing (as if that were possible!), put a cool damp towel or cloth over the boob in question, and take both Tylenol and Advil at the same time, plus Benadryl for the itching.  It would never occur to me to take two different pain meds together, but she said they're metabolized differently and the combination would help.  In general, she seemed to be telling me I was going to feel a lot worse over the next few weeks than I am right now.  Awesome.  I may be canceling or shortening the vacation I had planned for two weeks from now -- partly because of this, partly because of the sick cat who I don't feel good about leaving with just her catsitter once a day.  Onward and upward!

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2011 11:48AM Eloise wrote: michcon, I decided against tamoxifen.  I don't want to suggest that you should too, it was just what felt right for my particular circumstances and risk tolerance.  I only had DCIS and it was borderline whether I even needed rads, my surgeon said I wouldn't, the rad oncologist talked me into it.  He knew I was leaning against tamox, and said he really thought I should do either rads or tamox but doing both wouldn't add that much benefit.  He estimated my risk of a recurrence if I did nothing after surgery at around 10-12%, if I did either rads or tamox it would go down to 4-5%, if I did both it would be 2-3%.  So adding tamox would only give me another 1-2% of benefit.  Not worth it for me for five years of potential side effects. Tamox would reduce the chance of cancer in my other breast which rads won't, but I'm not too worried about that, I've had a lot of abnormal mammos, calcifications, and one previous biopsy on the breast that had the cancer, and the other one's been clean.  Everyone's situation is so different that I don't think you can use the specifics of mine as a guide, but the process of weighing pros and cons can be similar.  I read parts of the two very long threads "Bottle O'Tamoxifen" in the Hormonal section and "Natural girls" in the Alternative section, and that was helpful to me in getting an idea about how people who do have side effects described them.  Of course, people who aren't having side effects are less likely to come here in the first place or to post about them.  Many other posters have said that you can always get the tamoxifen, take it for a few weeks, and see how you feel, quit if it's too unpleasant.
Posts.Title: January 2011 Rads suzieq60 msjag

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 08:00PM Eloise wrote: #21 today.  The skin that's affected, basically a strip from just above the nipple across to the underarm, and under the breast, is still red, itchy, peeling in places.  The rest of the treatment field is absolutely normal, not even a bit of tan.  In the shower this morning, I was looking at my radiated armpit and thought "Hey, I thought the hair was supposed to fall out...".  Since I'm not allowed to shave, it's practically long enough to braid, as my mother used to say.  It turns out my cat was freaking out and bit me yesterday because she's hyperthyroid, so now I have medication to give her, for the rest of her life, or unless I want to have her treated with radioactive iodine.  I wanted to ask the vet if I could just give her some regular iodine and take her along to my last few treatments, but I didn't.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2011 08:28AM - edited Mar 20, 2011 08:34AM by Eloise Hardy, if this is your first consultation, that is, you haven't met with the radiation oncologist at all, then this will be the meeting at which she or he makes recommendations about your treatment and talks about the process of radiation. There will probably be a brief physical exam and a health history. At this initial meeting you might also meet a nurse who will tell you about what kind of skin protocols this doctor recommends, or they might leave this for a later appointment. It would certainly be okay to bring a friend, I'd think, they'd only have to step out for the physical exam. I didn't, but I saw other patients at my rads clinic who had friends or family with them at various times. This is the meeting at which you'll get the most amount of information, and also a stage where you need to decide whether you want to do the radiation at all -- so if it's helpful for you to have a second pair of ears/someone you can talk things over with later, that's a good reason to bring someone. If you've already had that meeting, then this planning session will be measurements, tattoos, and so on, and I think anyone who came with you would have to stay in the waiting room.

Posts.Title: Help me find an answer please Polyana anneflorida

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2011 05:47PM Eloise wrote: What I'd ask if it were me:  How large is the area that you expect to be remove?  Will there be any long-term changes to the appearance of the breast afterward? (and for you: If there are possible permanent/long-term changes, are you comfortable with them, or what corrective options are available -- assuming no further surgery is required?) What kind of anesthesia would be used during the procedure?  (Are you comfortable with this answer?  There are usually options.) How will the surgical team identify the area that needs to be biopsied?  (Usually, if you'd had a successful core biopsy, there'd be a clip left in the area, then the day of your wide excision/lumpectomy you'd have a wire localization process where a mammogram would locate the clip and put a guide wire into the tissue for the surgeon.  Without a clip, I suppose they could locate the calcifications or other suspicious areas with a mammogram and put the wire in that way...but find out what the plan is.) How long would recovery time be?  (It varies from person to person and also depending on what the "normal activities" are that you're trying to return to....get a good idea of what restrictions there might be.  Will you be able to shower, drive, lift things more than 5 pounds the day after surgery?  If you can't do any of those things (and my discharge instructions said not to) can you still go to work or do whatever else you need to do?)
Posts.Title: Any questions I should be asking about an excisional biopsy? Robynmummy Robynmummy

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2010 09:04PM Eloise wrote: Sue, I was interested to read that you're a "crier" at the dentist -- I am too, not all the time but often enough that all of my dentists have experienced it.  I try to let them know beforehand that if it happens, it's not because I'm in pain or frightened of the procedures, it's just....something my tear ducts do.  It seems to happen more often with upper teeth than lower, and I've always wondered if there's some kind of trigger to my sinuses that's a little closer to the upper teeth in me than it is in most people.   Anyway, I've had two stereotactic biopsies, both in the same breast but in different quadrants, at two different facilities (and two different results -- the first one benign, the second one DCIS). The first one hurt a bit when they took some of the samples, and I did cry for a little while; it wasn't a problem.  The second one didn't hurt at all, although the overall experience was more uncomfortable because I'd had a neck and shoulder injury a few months before.   I used an iPod for the first one, at the facility's suggestion, but I'm not sure I'd recommend it.  I had chosen very slow music since I didn't want to be wiggling and jiggling to the beat....but unfortunately most of the songs I had that were slow enough were sad songs; maybe that was why I started crying. For the second one, I'd loaded my iPod with a book on tape, but I forgot to charge up the battery, so no go.  I think I'd rather be listening and responding to the doctor and the techs anyway.  I talked through the whole procedure both times.   The most helpful thing was at the second facility, one of the mammo techs gave me a squeeze ball to hold (in the hand on the opposite side -- far enough away that the movement didn't translate).  That really helped a lot -- it gave me something else physical to focus on.  Maybe see if you can find one, in case your facility doesn't have them. Good luck, and don't worry about the tears!
Posts.Title: Somewhat Silly Stereotactic Biopsy Questions JellyShoes JellyShoes

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 02:00PM Eloise wrote: LovemyLife12 -- I'm guessing you had a lumpectomy and SNB sometime since late November, so it wouldn't be unusual for you to still have some occasional soreness from the surgery, and the exercise might be accentuating that.  But do talk to your RO about it. As far as exercise in general, my RO recommended keeping up with it during rads -- he said it would help fight the fatigue and improve circulation which would improve the effectiveness of treatment -- as long as you give yourself permission to take a day or two off towards the end if you're feeling like it's too much.  For me, that day was yesterday, day 21 of radiation, and it was partly fatigue and stress, partly that I have a sore patch of skin under my arm and was trying not to chafe it further. Good luck with the tape.  I find the visible one of my tattoos annoying, but I don't know how I would have kept tape in exactly the right place all this time.
Posts.Title: Starting Rads tomorrow Questions? LovemyLife12 BrandyB

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2013 03:22AM Eloise wrote: Claire, I had my surgery around Thanksgiving 2010 and didn't start radiation until well into January 2011. I didn't even have my radiology consult until just after Christmas. As I recall, my radiation oncologist said they had to wait for a few weeks after surgery in order for whatever inflammation might result from the procedure to settle down, so the X-rays they do to calculate the precise area to be irradiated will be accurate. So you should be good for the holidays.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed Stage 0, Grade 2, PR positive 80%, PG positive 20% ClaireFraser candi07

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2012 04:50PM Eloise wrote: First stereotactic biopsy for calcifications - my doctor called me about 10 days later and said it was benign -- in a very "why did you waste our time with this" tone of voice, as if it had been my idea! Second stereotactic biopsy for calcifications, same area of the same breast, different doctor/HMO, two years later -- the radiologist called me about 48 hours after the biopsy.  I was having my hair washed at the salon and I heard my cell phone ringing -- it was in my purse back at the stylist's station.  I thought "oh -- I think that's the doc calling to tell me I have cancer".  But I figured there was no point in listening to the message and getting upset about it, I might as well get the haircut I was there for.  When I called the radiologist back an hour later, he told me it was DCIS, he didn't have the stage yet, and that a breast care coordinator would call within an hour with an appointment for a surgeon (which she did).  He was very sweet about it.  I wouldn't have wanted to go back to his office, it was miles out of my way and a fee to park.
Posts.Title: How did you hear biopsy results--phone or appt? frazzledmom schoolmom

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2011 08:47PM Eloise wrote: Sharon, wow, that's scary about your dentist.  I know radiation to the mouth and throat area does that, because my mom had rads for an oral cancer and it basically burnt out her salivary glands so she had a dry mouth for the rest of her life.  But I'd never heard that radiation elsewhere in the body could have that effect.  I hope it's short-term for you. Tekiya, I'm glad you had a good time in Jamaica.  But no report on the pool boys?
Posts.Title: February 2011 Rads ToriGirl Elisimo

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 02:12AM Eloise wrote: I had #13 of 25 today so I've passed the halfway mark!  A bit of fatigue, but hard for me to be sure it's rads-related because I tend to be pretty low energy at the best of times.  I have red patches under my breast and around my nipple, but otherwise no skin discoloration.  But my doc, who I saw today, told me to expect more fatigue and skin problems before I see him next week.  And now another topic from those of us with experience for those just starting out! It's time for What Not To Wear -- The Radiation Edition.   DON'T wear a tight skirt, tight pants, or tight underwear.  You're going to be lying on a table and inching your butt up and down and around on it, and then lying very still.  So you really don't want a wedgie. DON'T wear a dress, since you'll have to take it off and expose your butt to the passing parade. DON'T wear a lot of perfume, because the next person to be treated in your room might be having problems with smells and nausea.  I don't think you have to go all out with unscented products, just don't add anything you don't have to.  DO wear cute shoes or socks if you have them, because it'll give the techs something to talk to you about. DO bring along a hoodie or cardigan if you want, especially on doctor day when you'll be going beyond the dressing room-treatment room corridor.  Both for modesty and warmth, it's nice to have it to put it on over your exam gown as you walk over to the doctor's office.  If you don't have one, the techs will usually give you a blanket or you can take a second gown and wear it back to front.  What am I forgetting here? chime in!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Rads ToriGirl Elisimo

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 03:41AM Eloise wrote: JB -- I went to work after my first biopsy. I was uncomfortable -- particularly because the breast center had given me a large-size ice pack and it looked pretty weird stuffed down the front of my bra -- but it was certainly doable.  For my second one, I was on a work schedule where I had already worked a whole shift before my biopsy.  For me, the post-procedure breast pain was not so much an issue as the stiffness from having to lie still in an uncomfortable position.   The ideal bra is something that compresses your breasts snugly, a sports bra that smushes them together is excellent, but I don't think you need to go out and get one just for this.  If you do, though, a front-closing cotton bra is a useful thing to have if you need some additional procedures.   Another thing that you might look for is a squeeze ball -- the staff at my second biopsy gave me one to hold, and it was amazing how much the desire to move my neck or stretch my back (which I couldn't do) was relieved by being able to move just the hand on the other side from the biopsy. My first clinic told me to bring an iPod if I wanted, my second one didn't, but at that one the doctor and one of the techs made a point of talking to me throughout so I wouldn't have wanted the distraction of music. Good luck, and I hope your results are benign!

Posts.Title: Stereotactic tips, anyone? jadeblue jadeblue

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2010 01:58AM Eloise wrote: I had one on Wednesday.  Jen's description is good -- if you've never had surgery or been hospitalized (I hadn't), it seems like a big deal, but it wasn't really.  The terms "excisional biopsy", "wide excision", and "lumpectomy" seem to be used interchangeably, so anything you read about a lumpectomy should apply.  It's outpatient surgery, I had "conscious sedation" but I remember nothing from the time I was rolling into the OR to when I woke up in recovery, and didn't feel especially groggy or disoriented when I did wake up -- just really dehydrated.  I checked in for my wire localization at 8:15 am and was home by 3:30 pm.  You'll need someone to drive you home.  I took Vicodin the first night but it made me vomit, and the next day I found I didn't need it so just using Advil now. The area is sensitive, especially when I bend over, but nothing terrible -- not as bad as bad dental pain or menstrual cramps for me. I was able to drive in my neighborhood yesterday and took a shower today.  If I'd absolutely had to go to work or cook a family dinner or something like that today, I could have probably managed it, but I didn't so I stayed in bed or puttered around the house.  Jen is right about the sports bras, I'm double-teaming it with cotton shelf-bra camisoles from J. Jill and adding during the day a zip-front sports bra from Sears for extra compression.   Putting a pillow over the breast in question is also a good idea at night, particularly if you share your bed with anyone like my cat who's inclined to pounce on sleeping people.  Best of luck and hang in there!
Posts.Title: can someone describe excisional biopsy? momand2kids brooke1120

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2010 01:53PM Eloise wrote: Brooke, you can scroll up and see my post from 11/19 when I was two days out from my excisional biopsy. Now I'm two weeks + 1 day.  I haven't needed any pain meds since probably the third or fourth day after surgery -- still have odd little sensations from time to time which I understand may be nerves healing back -- but not painful.  The incision is healed over, has occasionally been a little itchy, but no big deal.  I am finding it more comfortable to wear my light shelf-bra camisoles at night still, but I've gone without a couple of nights and it's fine.  I can sleep on that side now if I want, I couldn't the first week or so. I've gone back to normal daily activities, although I'm pretty sedentary, but have gone to the gym a couple of times, lifted weights and ridden bike, etc. with no problems.  My breast wasn't very bruised at first, and now it really looks like someone punched me, but my surgeon said that was normal.   The wire localization didn't hurt at all -- even putting in the needle for the local anesthetic was not painful.  The radiologist and tech were very adamant about telling me not to look down while they were doing it -- i.e. don't look at the wire sticking out of you.  They had a picture on the opposite side of the room and told me to focus on that.  The process was way more comfortable than the stereotactic core biopsy because I was sitting in a chair.  It was a little weird only because my hospital has a satellite office where they do all the ob-gyn and thus all the mammography and radiology -- so I had to go there for the wire loc, then -- wearing two hospital gowns and a blanket, plus my street shoes -- get transferred in a wheelchair and ambulance about a mile down the road to the main hospital, and go through the whole admitting process there before going to the pre-op room.  But it was fine....fortunately it was a sunny Northern California day so I didn't catch cold! It is really nerve-wracking to go through all of these unknowns, but hang in there!  It's great that your docs think you've found this at the stage of being a precursor to malignancy rather than an actual cancer.  Even though I did have DCIS, I didn't have to have any further treatment after the excision, so hoping your luck is as good as mine.
Posts.Title: can someone describe excisional biopsy? momand2kids brooke1120

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2011 11:07PM Eloise wrote: I had my last rads session 11 days ago.  Today, I looked in the mirror and thought if I didn't know which breast had been radiated, I wouldn't be able to tell.  It's very slightly redder in one area, there's a little patch of dry skin, but essentially it's healed.  Fatigue is still with me though.  Yesterday I had a meeting to go to at work and put on an actual BRA -- well, not an underwire one, a cotton wirefree one, but still, not a camisole.  And then I put on a DRESS for the first time in two months....without having to think about how I'd have to take it off for rads and walk around the clinic in a half-slip and a gown.  Progress!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Rads ToriGirl Elisimo

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2011 11:12PM Eloise wrote: nondairy971 -- At your very first appointment, the radiologist will probably just examine you, talk to you about how radiation works, and tell you what course of treatment she or he is thinking about prescribing.  You may also meet some of the other staff at this visit, the nurse, radiology techs, and social worker.  If you have a good team, this should be a real opportunity to ask a lot of questions. The appointment after that will be the longest one -- you'll get a CT scan and the process of mapping out the radiation will begin.  You'll probably get tattoos at this one, unless your center does non-permanent markers.  Mine didn't hurt; they're three small dots, the one that's between my breasts is visually annoying and I might get it removed or covered with something else after I'm done, the other two are on my sides and I can't see them unless I'm really looking.  The CT scan won't hurt but you will need to lie still for several minutes at a time.  You may also get further instruction from the nurse about skin care at this appointment or the next one. At appointment #3, probably a week or so later, the team will look at the plan that the doctor and the team have worked out, do an X-ray or two, take more measurements.  Time-consuming, but nothing hard for you.  Either at this appointment or at #2, they'll talk to you about what schedule you prefer for the regular treatment.  At my clinic this appointment is combined with the first treatment but that isn't always the case. Then your treatment begins. Usually they'll schedule you for the same time every day, or close to the same time.  If things are running well, you'll be in and out in less than 15 minutes.  Come in, strip to the waist and stow your stuff in a locker, put on a gown, the tech takes you back to your treatment room. I have the same three techs every day and they're sweet.  They'll help you lie down on the table and take your arms out of your sleeves and pull the gown down to your waist, you'll put your arms over your head in a padded cradle with a ring to hold on to -- quite comfortable.  My techs offer warm blankets for my legs and abdomen. They will take a few minutes to nudge and tug you around on the table to the precise point where all the tattoos and the marks on the table line up where they should be.  This is what I find hardest: learning to let them move my body and not try to help -- just be dead weight -- and if the third tech comes in the room after I'm lying down, to remember not to put my head up to make eye contact when he says hello to the bottom of my feet!  When you're in position, they'll cover up the breast on the side that isn't being treated (they need to expose that side at first in order to get the marks to line up). Then the techs will leave the room and go into the control room.  They'll be able to see, hear, and talk to you.  The machine will turn on, whir, move around, while a sequence of beeps and buzzers reminds everyone else not to go in the room.  It's not loud -- reminds me of a fax/copier sound.  You need to lie very still, but you can breathe normally.  Some places let you choose music (mine doesn't), some have special artwork on the ceiling to focus on (my room is named Sequoia, so there are lots of tree and leaf images). I don't feel anything, although some people report feeling a slight warmth.  This actual radiation sequence is maybe about three minutes long.  Then they'll come back, help you off the table, walk you back to the changing room, and you're done.  Once a week you'll meet with your doc afterwards for a quick exam and chance to ask questions.  I don't think radiation should add to any pain you're having now.  It shouldn't affect what you can eat or what you want to eat, and in fact the docs don't want you to change your diet during radiation -- not to stress your body further, and also so you stay the same size and the measurements don't get thrown off.   It will give you fatigue, more so as the treatments go on and for a month or so afterward, possibly more.  Your skin will be affected, and you'll need to put creams on several times a day -- each doctor or clinic seems to have their own regimen, but basically they're all moisturizers.  The skin will probably be red, possibly itchy and may peel like a sunburn. Most of us have been advised to avoid underwires and very constricting bras while the skin is healing and to go for camisoles, soft sports bras, or go without when possible. Undershirts or tanks are good to stop the rest of your clothes getting gooped up from the creams.  The nurse at my clinic had me buy a yard of white fleece to cut into strips and put next to my skin, though I haven't needed it yet. Hope some of that helps!  I'm only on day 11 so I haven't had much in the way of side effects.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Rads ToriGirl Elisimo

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2011 05:58PM Eloise wrote: I had #15 of 25 on Friday.  I have a pink/red area under my breast where the skin's started to peel and is somewhat itchy.  My nipple and the surrounding area, basically the highest part of the breast when I'm lying down, is pink but not itchy or tender.  The rest of my skin shows no discoloration at all, though my doctor keeps saying he expects a tanned rectangle to show up any day now.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Rads ToriGirl Elisimo

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2011 01:57PM Eloise wrote: Juanita, I don't know how contagious the baby is at this stage, but I think your sister should respect your wishes.  It might not be the best place for the baby either, when she's already sick and could pick up a secondary infection from someone.  I had to go to the emergency room on Presidents Day (totally unrelated to this, my cat bit me!), which was, of course, full of sniffling, sneezing, coughing kids, and a few days later I got a very bad cold, which I'm still sick with. Maybe I would have still been just as sick if I hadn't gone to the ER, or if I wasn't getting rads. But it hasn't helped my recovery. One week since my last radiation, and I have the energy level of a slug.  My skin, however, is looking great, better than it did since day one of rads.  The part under the arm, which ten days ago was so red and blistered it hurt me to move my arm, is a very pale tan. The breast is still a little pink, but the pink of a moderate sunburn.  So keep lubing the boob, everyone!  This too shall pass!  BTW I found with the Miaderm tubes that there was a lot of cream left in the tube after it appeared to be empty. I cut the tube open with the kitchen shears and got another day's worth out of it.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Rads ToriGirl Elisimo

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2011 08:20PM Eloise wrote: mjbmiller, so happy for you to be done.  I had #18 today and had my "doctor day".  In the last week I've gone from a small red area under my breast to a larger red stripe all around the radiated side of my body, like a bra-band reaction.  My nipple area is still red and I have a red patch starting under my armpit, but not even a hint of tan anywhere else in the treated area.  My doc brought his nurse in to consult; he thought it might be a yeast infection but she put her finger on the red part and it turned white, then red again, which apparently means it's not yeast.  So I'm supposed to take Advil every six hours to reduce the inflammation, and put Neosporin under my breast and cover it with gauze, then put on the other moisturizing agents. We'll see.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Rads ToriGirl Elisimo

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 01:08AM Eloise wrote: I had #20 today, just one week to go.  Still having a lot of redness and itchiness, but only under the breast, around the nipple, and a small spot under the arm.  I broke down and ordered some Miaderm which I've been using since Tuesday; it feels soothing going on and the consistency is less gloppy than the Cetaphil I was using.  I hope that between having three days off for Presidents' Day and using the Miaderm, things will get better soon.  My fatigue is manageable but I'm working a very reduced schedule -- about 10 hours a week from my usual 50 (two jobs).  I'm so glad I had sick time banked up. What I'm finding more bothersome, and it may just be me, is that even if I'm not especially sleepy or tired, I don't want to do much of anything except watch TV or read or surf the web. All my grand ideas about reorganizing the closets, shopping for a new car, etc. during my leave have gone up in smoke so far!  Elaine, I'm also planning to go on vacation shortly after my last session....others have told me it should be doable....and for you, since you'll be with your sister, she'll be understanding if there's a day when you want to stay in or rest in the middle of the day instead of running around the city?

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2011 08:08PM Eloise wrote: Tori, the ointment I have is Earth Friendly Baby's Organic Calendula Daily Care Cream. I'm just using that on the bits where I'm noticing reddening, which are under the breast and the nipple. It's very goopy and messy....I'm putting it on before bedtime and first thing in the AM (my rad appt is at 3 pm).  On the whole rlght front side of my upper torso I'm using Cetaphil moisturizing cream from the drugstore, which is what my RO's nurse recommended, 3-5 times a day but not within 2 hours of radiation. It's the cream which comes in a jar, not the lotion.  I have some pure aloe too, but haven't really used it. My doc said to add in hydrocortisone 1% when it starts to itch. Day 11, and my hands are getting nice and soft with all the leftover products! I started to compose new lyrics to "Row, Row, Row Your Boat"....who wants to add on? Lube, lube, lube your boob, Use a ton of cream, Stickily, stickily, stickily, stickily, Rads is but a dream.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Rads ToriGirl Elisimo

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2011 05:03PM Eloise wrote: Elizabeth, re timeline between surgery and rads....: I had my lumpectomy on 11/17/10, but didn't see a radiation oncologist until 12/23/10, and didn't start rads until 1/24/11.  Part of the delay was that my surgeon didn't think I needed any further treatment and so I didn't push to get oncology appointments sooner, and the delay between my initial radiation consult and treatment was because I signed up to qualify for a clinical study of herceptin for DCIS, which meant I needed to get tissue samples tested for HER2 at the lab that was heading the research study on the other side of the country. As it turned out, I'm HER2- so I didn't go into the study.  Anyway, my radiation oncologist said that total interval of 11 weeks between surgery and radiation was longer than he liked in general, but he felt it was okay in my case since I had such a small area of DCIS.  It was really my decision as to whether to do rads at all; my Van Nuys score puts me in the surgery-only category, but I have a lot of family history of various cancers early in life.

Posts.Title: Cluster calcifications found on mammogram OJulie67 gill27

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2010 01:22PM Eloise wrote: To your P. S., the hormone results will come from this tissue sample, but from looking at my report, it was done by a different lab tech after the initial diagnosis. With mine the timeline was: Mon 10/18: I have the biopsy Wed 10/20: Path lab report diagnoses DCIS Thurs 10/21: Radiologist calls to inform me of that and sets up surgeon appt Tues 10/26: Path lab details ER+/PR+ and produces report in the morning, I meet with surgeon in the afternoon and get report.   I did have to ask my surgeon for a printout of the report, he didn't offer it -- but had no objection. I think many docs don't realize how much information is available to patients online and elsewhere, they're still in the mindset of thinking they need to interpret these mysterious numbers and letters to us.   I didn't have an invasive cancer so I can't help with the first part of your question, except to suggest that the surgery recommendation for multiple tumors may also depend on your breast size and where the tumors are -- it might not be possible to get a good result with lumpectomy if they're taking two chunks out of different sides of a small breast. Best of luck!

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2011 04:49PM Eloise wrote: Julie, baby and body powders are generally fine to use during rads, and you can use deodorant that doesn't contain aluminum such as Tom's of Maine.  Check the label carefully -- some organic-y health food store brands still have aluminum.
